Our love affair with Milton Averyâ€™s work began in 1967 when Donald Morris and his wife Florence introduced us to his paintings in their gallery in Northwest Detroit.Â  Today, after seeing more than two dozen exhibitions of his work over these fifty plus years, our attachment remains strong.Â Â  So we lost no time in driving to the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Connecticut (less than an hour from New York City,) to see this unusual show that brings together a dozen paintings each and numerous sketches by three members of the Avery family: Milton, his wife Sally Michel, and their daughter March.Â Â  This triple treat was curated by Kenneth Silver with Stephanie Guyet.

The Averys spent virtually all of their summers together in favored locations in Massachusetts, Vermont and New Hampshire as well as in more distant destinations in Mexico, Canada, and Europe.Â  In each place they sketched the mountains and the seas, the forests and the beaches as well as family members and friends.Â Â  Often, they were able to complete watercolors of those scenes while still on vacation.Â  They would then take their drawings back to New York where Milton would develop many of his into oil paintings during the winter months. Why this show is so significant is that it provides an opportunity to appreciate what Robert Hobbs has called â€œthe Avery styleâ€, common to the three artists.

First and foremost, Milton, Sally and March are outstanding colorists.Â  Milton was called, early on, â€œthe American Matisseâ€ because of his use of extremely vivid, often unnamable colors.Â  Whether subtle and serene like Sea Gazers (1956) from the Whitney Museum or agitated and restless like Breaking Wave (1959) from the Neuberger Museum, Miltonâ€™s colors range from strikingly vivid to peacefully harmonious.Â  Other characteristics of this familyâ€™s style are the flat picture plane, often interlocking simple shapes and over time, greater simplicity of forms.Â  The Avery Style was far more than charming.Â  As Milton grew older and more frail, one could see in his solitary figures or animals his acceptance of isolation and his recognition of impending death.Â  But then, each of the artists seemed comfortable with painting figures who did not communicate with each other.

Milton grew up near Hartford, Connecticut and in 1920, at the age of 35, he spent the first of several summers in Gloucester in order to be able to sketch from nature.Â Â  Four years later, while there, he met Sally Michel, an aspiring painter and illustrator who was almost 20 years his junior, and followed her to New York City in 1925.Â  They married the next year and Milton Â painted every weekday for close to forty years, reserving their weekends for galleries, museums and trips to friends.Â  Seeing Matisse and Picasso opened up new options for Milton in color and form and he continued to experiment with flattened surfaces, interlocking forms and both bold and muted colors throughout his career.Â Â  Taciturn by nature, Miltonâ€™s sketches and his paintings often provided an outlet for his wit and humor.Â  Milton belonged to no art movement or art school and continually forged his own path, a trait greatly admired by Gottlieb and Rothko.

Milton Avery, Swimmers and Sunbathers, 1945. Oil on canvas, 28 x 48 1/4 inches. Â© 2019 Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

Beyond the water is a horizontal line of light blue and white boulders and above that at the top of the painting, is a dark olive-green abstracted forest.Â Â  As in GaspÃ© Landscape, the various elements in Swimmers and Bathers appear to be harmoniously coordinated, another Avery trait.

It is hard to imagine what Miltonâ€™s career might have been like without Sally Michel. Sally recognized Miltonâ€™s potential when she married him and did everything she could to allow him to develop both his craft and his style. It is just as hard to imagine what Sallyâ€™s career would have been like without Milton. Luckily, March is the subject of a concurrent show in New York at the Blum & Poe Gallery with more than two dozen paintings done between 1963 and 2018.Â  It provides several examples of the mature Avery style in her domestic scenes, still lives and landscapes.Â  Several reveal the simple interlocking shapes and bold colors of Miltonâ€™s advanced paintings such as her Family Tea (1965), Ruth in a Sling Chair (1985), and Card Players (1983), but they are clearly her own.Â  For example, Family Tea (1965) is perfectly balanced with a series of subtly combined colors in the motherâ€™s jacket, lap, and seat.Â  But, the facial features of both the mother and the older child as well as the pitcher and tea set are more realistically drawn.
